title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We saw the splendid scenery to such great advantaee on both sides : Ben Laivers, with small waterfalls descending its sides, amid other high mountains wooded here and there ; with Kenmore in the distance ; the view, looking back, as the loch winds, was most beautiful.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: A pleasant excursion may be made to the Falls of Acharn, a cascade tvt'o miles from Kenmore, and half a mile off the road on the south side of the loch.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Along the north bank of the river, there is a terrace sixteen yards wide and three miles in length, overshadowed by a row of stately beech trees, and on the opposite side, there is a similar walk extending a mile from Kenmore.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: ground a portion of the lake is seen, with the village and church of Kenmore, and to the north of them, a light bridge spans the Tay, immediately behind which is the little wooded island.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The most remarkable object in the vicinity of Kenmore is

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The scenery at and round Kenmore is of the finest and most pleasing description, and includes all the elements of the picturesque — the grandeur of mountain scenery, the beauty and softness of the woodland, and the freshness of the stream and lake.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Kenmore

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: DUNKELD TO KENMORE— (22 miles).

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The tourist now descends along the edge of another deep and wooded dell, bordered by sloping cultivated ground, and passing Coshieville Inn, reaches rortingall, as the lower part of Glen Lyon is called ; and crossing the Lyon by a boat, a good road through the policies of Taymouth conducts the tourist to the lovely village of Kenmore, where there is an excellent hotel, the Breadalbane Arms.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: * From the bridge of Tummel, an alpine road of thirteen miles in length leads to Strath Tay and Kenmore.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: At Callandar we were poorly accommodated ; an American clergyman from Boston, who had-preached the day before at the Free Church, built by the Marquis of Breadalbane at Kenmore, and who was travelling with his son, was grossly insulted by the head-waiter, for not carving a piece of roast- beef in a square fashion ; so great was the insult we could not but notice it ; calling in the landlord, we demanded that the offender should not appear again in our presence ; a slight apology and compliance with our demand satisfied us.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: He complained, that at Kenmore,  the tavern people, finding him without baggage, had placed him for the night in the garret, and begged me to spare him something from my superabundance to carry to the hotel at Callandar, lest he would be again treated as a servant.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: The " Birks of Aberfeldy" have been celebrated by Burns and others, but it was almost certain if I stopped to examine them, that the next stage would be full ; at Kenmore, a beautiful village at the head of Loch Tay, near Taymouth Castle, a dozen travellers were thus disappointed, some of whom had tried in vain to procure seats for several days ; this admonished me to proceed with only a hasty glance at the magnificent seat of the Marquis of Breadalbane.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: The road from Dunkeld to Kenmore passes Aberfeldy, where English summer tourists stop to visit the Falls of Moness.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: Dunkeld to Kenmore — Aberfeldy — Taymouth Castle — Visit of the Queen — A ranger iiilled— Extent of Breadalbane's possessions — A managing lady and daughters— A cockney — Callandar — More Americans  — Commercial travellers — Sees— Loch Katrine — Row on the lake— Steamboat sunk— Gaelic — Loch Lomond— Glenfalloch — Ben Lomond— Scotch sign — Dumbarton Castle — Glasgow — Refuge for houseless poor — The Kirk — Sir Walter's monument.

title: Diary, reminiscences, and correspondence of Henry Crabb Robinson ...
author: Robinson, Henry Crabb
snippet: I will abridge from my journal : " It was in the forenoon, a few miles from Kenmore, when, on the highroad,  I was startled by a screaming noise, which I at first mistook  for quarrelling ; till, coming to a hedge, which I overlooked,  I beheld a scene which the greatest of landscape-paint- ers in the historic line might have delighted to represent.

title: Diary, reminiscences, and correspondence of Henry Crabb Robinson ...

snippet: On Sunday, the 23d, by Killin to Kenmore.

title: John Splendid;
author: Munro, Neil
snippet: It was not the fishing season; but the street thronged with fishers from Kenmore and Cairn- dhu and Kilcatrine and the bays of lower Cowal.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: Sir James Hastings' English regiment, and those of Levea and Mackay belonging to Scotland, were arrayed in that bright scarlet which was to become so famous in future wars ; but the battalions of Balfour, liamsay, and Kenmore, wore the black iron caps, the scarlet hose, and yellow coats of the Scotch-Dutch brigade.

snippet: Archibald's first separation from this excellent mother was ■when he went to the Grammar School at Kenmore, in Bi-eadalbane.

snippet: It Avasover the mantelpiece of the inn parlour at Kenmore that Burns Avroteperhaps the finest of his English heroics, the lines beginning " Admiringnature in her Avildest grace."

snippet: The Earl of Marr had a gallantarmy in Scotland, and Lord Derwentwater, withForster, Kenmore, Winterton, and others, wereassembling forces on the Border.

snippet: AtKenmore, in fact, they are very considerable.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: At both ends of Loch Tay, as well at Kenmore as atKillin, there are the remains of ancient Druidical temples.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: I begged him to present my acknowledgmentsto his worthy mistress, and the same morning proceeded on myfarther journey, on foot, after having enjoyed a tolerable portionof roast beef, although not quite so much as the Highlanders whoexhibited their games and dances before the Queen, in the park ofKenmore, who dispatched 163 sheep, 11 oxen, and I know nothow many calves.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: In the thickets of the park at Kenmore, they hadeven naturalized buffaloes.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: But this at Kenmore has the peculiarity,that it is entirely built of a snow-white limestone, found in abundance in the neighbourhood, gi\ ing the structure all the appearanceof a palace of congealed milk.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: As I now anticipated an agreeable and pleasant morning, I invited a small party for the evening, as good as the little village ofKenmore could furnish, namely, mine host and his family, theschoolmaster of the place, and a farmer of the neighbourhood,whose acquaintance I had made upon my road.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: " I have visited the three fair and great islands over which themajesty of Britain rules, and now I am arrived here among thepoor inhabitants of the little village of Kenmore, who boast tohave been attached to the illustrious family of Breadalbane, fromtime immemorial, as vassals and namesakes.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: The Breadalbanes are hence only the largest branch (not the stem)of the great house of Argyll, and the marquis is only the chieftainof a branch ofthe Campbells.*Close to the lake there is also a pretty little village, called Kenmore, with a comfortable inn, in which I took up my abode.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: ItsEnglish name is Taymouth Castle; its Celtic, Kenmore, as theEnglish write it, or as it ought properly to be written, " Ceanmore," that is, the great chief, or great head.* Both names seemto be equally well known, not only in the locality, but also inmaps, where sometimes the one and sometimes the other appears.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: Not only Aberfeldy, but Kenmore, Killin, and severalother places in this direction, Burns, whom Scott calls the best ofScottish poets, has celebrated in his charming songs.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: This route proceeds by Aberfeldy, Kenmore, (the noble seat of the noble Marquis of Breadalbane,) from hence to Loch Tay, through Killin to Loch Earn,and then back.
